item.title: Python Bot Delivered Through DLL Side-Loading, (Tue, Mar 18th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: One of my hunting rules triggered some suspicious Python code, and, diving deeper, I found an interesting example of DLL side-loading. This technique involves placing a malicious DLL with the same name and export structure as a legitimate DLL in a location the application checks first, causing the application to load the malicious DLL instead of the intended one. This is a classic vulnerability seen for years in many software. The attacker also implemented simple tricks to bypass classic security controls.

item.title: Static Analysis of GUID Encoded Shellcode, (Mon, Mar 17th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: I wanted to figure out how to statically decode the GUID encoded shellcode Xavier wrote about in his diary entry "Shellcode Encoded in UUIDs".

item.title: Mirai Bot now incroporating (malformed?) DrayTek Vigor Router Exploits, (Sun, Mar 16th)
item.source: SANS Internet Storm Center, InfoCON: green
item.content:encoded: Last October, Forescout published a report disclosing several vulnerabilities in DrayTek routers. According to Forescount, about 700,000 devices were exposed to these vulnerabilities [1]. At the time, DrayTek released firmware updates for affected routers [2]. Forescout also noted that multiple APTs targeting devices.

item.title: Off the Beaten Path: Recent Unusual Malware
item.author: Dominik Reichel
item.content:encoded: Three unusual malware samples analyzed here include an ISS backdoor developed in a rare language, a bootkit and a Windows implant of a post-exploit framework.
